newsitem.title: POLAND: Gdansk refinery workers reach deal with management.
newsitem.headline: Gdansk refinery workers reach deal with management.

text.p: Workers at Poland's second largest oil refinery, Rafineria Gdanska SA, reached a deal with management on pay and other issues but still demanded free shares, a union official said on Saturday.
"The trade unions have reached an agreement with the Rafineria Gdanska SA management," Andrzej Cenacewicz, head of the Solidarity union in the refinery, told Reuters.
He said it provided for pay increases of 17 percent this year in two stages, from February and from August.
In August the management will also introduce an extra day off work and unify principles for setting the pay of blue-collar and white-collar workers, he said.

Management officials said the deal ended a dispute at the firm, but unions the workers still sought free shares in the refinery, which is 75 percent owned by the state oil holding Nafta Polska SA and 25 percent by the state.
The unions want a free 15 percent of shares in line with a privatisation bill passed last year, while management says this must wait until the law comes into force on April 8.

Cenacewicz said the workers would not hold any protest actions before March 17 as they expected the general shareholders' meeting of the refinery would alter its statutes so the shares can be handed over.
"We will direct our demands for the refinery workers to get free shares to its owners, Nafta Polska SA and the state treasury," he said.
Last month the unions held a brief warning strike at the refinery, which processes about three million tonnes of crude oil a year.
